conversation.content: So it's you—the anonymous investor who's been circling our company for three months, sending those, um, those aggressive buyout offers through lawyers. [bitter laugh] Of course it's you.
[quietly] Hello, Jamie.
Don't—don't do that, don't say my name like you have any right to it after fifteen years of absolute silence. [voice shaking]
[measured] I've been following your company's growth, the innovative platform you built from nothing—it's, uh, it's impressive work, truly impressive, better than anything I could've imagined.
Oh, so now you're proud? Where was that pride when Mom was working three jobs to keep us afloat while you were, what, flipping luxury condos in Miami?
That's not—[sighs] Look, I know how this looks, but I genuinely want to help, to invest properly, give you the capital to scale internationally.
[sharply] We don't need your money, we're doing fine with actual investors who don't abandon their families for, um, for profit margins and beachfront properties.
[defensive] It wasn't about the money, Jamie, it was never just about—I mean, your mother and I, we were destroying each other, you were too young to understand.
[trembling] I was twelve, not stupid—I understood plenty when you chose your business empire over your actual family, when you literally packed your things during my birthday party.
That timing was, uh, that was unfortunate, I admit that, but staying would've made things worse for everyone, including you. [pause] Especially you.
[quieter] You know what the worst part is? I actually built this whole company partly to, I don't know, to prove I didn't need anything from you, ever.
And you succeeded—you've built something remarkable without me, which is exactly why I want to be part of it now, if you'll let me. [hopeful]
[withdrawing] Being part of something means showing up when it's hard, not just when it's profitable or, um, convenient for your portfolio.
You're right, absolutely right, and I can't undo the past, but maybe, just maybe, we could try something different going forward? [tentative]
[long exhale] The board meeting is tomorrow at nine—if you're serious about this, you'll need to convince them, not me, that you're more than just another corporate vulture.
I'll be there, and Jamie, I'll—I'll present the real proposal, not the aggressive one, the one where we're partners, where your vision stays intact.
[softening slightly] Mom still asks about you sometimes, you know, even after everything—she'd probably want me to at least hear you out properly.
[emotional] She does? I, uh, I think about her too, about both of you, more than you'd probably believe, especially lately.
[firmly] Nine o'clock, conference room B—don't be late, because unlike fifteen years ago, I won't wait around wondering if you're actually going to show up.
I'll be early. [pause]

scenario: An e-commerce manager discovers their estranged father—a real estate mogul who abandoned the family years ago—is the mysterious investor trying to buy out their startup.
